channel.title: Help deleting a virus
channel.description:
I've got this problem with a certain virus, it's called "svchost.exe" I know what svchost really does, but this is a virus disguised.. I've scanned it with malware bytes and it says it's infected, I quarantine svchost and restart my computer, and look, it's back again. I'd like to try and get rid of it without doing a system restore. But if I must system restore, I will. I'm not very computer handy, so any help will be appreciated.
Edit: and i've made some progress.. last night i couldn't even delete it. But now I can, it just comes back within 3 seconds.

item.title: Help deleting a virus
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

RiiPiiNFtW:

I personally find Kaspersky the best. It reads java bytes and can determine any malicious content. It is expsensive though, :L.

I have kaspersky, worst fucking mistake i ever made. Russians spying on me is not my idea of good virus protection. I personally prefer Norton 2012 for basic needs like a firewall, malwarebytes to scan for rootkits, ccleaner to clean up the mess, and hijackthis to restore the peace.

Read full topic

item.title: Help deleting a virus
item.dc:creator: @chillwitm888 chillwitm888
item.description:
@chillwitm888 wrote:

[quote=“asshole_rule, post:19, topic:426308”][quote author=RiiPiiNFtW link=topic=529001.msg3859382#msg3859382 date=1324583878]
svchost.exe is not a virus. A virus just uses the .dll’s to run itself because Microsoft learned that .dll’s are easier to use but you have to have something to execute them. svchosts are used for normal computer functions.
[/quote]

Yea, I didn’t know what. I just assumed it was a virus because malwarbytes told me it was.[/quote]
Use Rising Antivirus!

Read full topic

item.title: Help deleting a virus
item.dc:creator: @Andrew_Ferguson The317Guy
item.description:
@Andrew_Ferguson wrote:

System restore is your best bet, they may have modified a system file so you can’t kill it and run it. They cause more damage in repairing them then they do from the actual functions.

Read full topic

item.title: Help deleting a virus
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

I AM NOT RESPONSIBLE IF YOU MESS UP YOUR PC <3

This worm duplicates itself to different locations of shared folders. The duplicated program uses a folder icon that has an .exe file extension. DO NOT double click on any of these folders.

If the operating system of the infected computer is either Windows Me or Windows XP, turn off System Restore while this fix is being implemented. To turn off System Restore within Windows Me, click Start > Settings > Control Panel. Double-click "System." Select "File System" from the Performance tab. Left click the "Troubleshooting" tab and check the "Disable System Restore" box. Click "OK."

Restart your computer in Safe Mode and log in as Administrator

Access the command prompt. Click Start > Run. Type “cmd.” Click OK > CD (change directory) from the command prompt, press the space bar.

Type the name of the full directory path of the folder containing your Windows system files. It will be either “C:\Windows\System” or “C:\Windows\System 32.”
4

From the command prompt, type the following to unprotect the files for removal:

“attrib -h -r -s scvhost.exe” and press “Enter;”

“attrib -h -r -s blastclnnn.exe” and press “Enter;”

“attrib -h -r -s autorun.inf” and press “Enter.”
5

Delete the files by typing the following from the command prompt:

“del scvhost.exe” and press “Enter;”

“del blastclnnn.exe” and press “Enter;”

“del autorun.ini” and press “Enter.”
6

Type “cd” to return to the main Windows directory.

Unprotect and delete the Autorun.inf file by typing the following from the Windows directory command prompt:

“attrib -h -r -s autorun.inf” and press “Enter;”

"del “autorun.inf” and press “Enter;”

Type “regedit” and press “Enter” to open the Registry Editor.
7

Locate the following entry:

HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run.

Delete the incorrectly spelled Yahoo! Messenger entry with the value

“c:\windows\system32\scvhost.exe.”
8

Locate the following key:

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon.

Within the key, there is a “shell” entry with the value of “explorer.exe, scvhost.exe”. Edit the entry to remove the reference to Scvhost.exe, leaving Explorer.exe as the remaining value in the registry entry.
9

Locate the following key:

HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE>SYSTEM>CurrentControlSet>Services>

Delete the following subkeys from the left panel:

RpcPatch

RpcTftpd

Exit the command prompt and return to the operating system. Type “Exit,” and press “Enter.”
10

Reboot the PC.

If Scvhost.exe still resides on the computer, repeat these steps or try using an automatic removal program from McAfee or Symantec (see links in References).

I got all this information mostly from ehow.com However, I have looked at several different places and this is the general step by step way of fixing

Read full topic

item.title: Help deleting a virus
item.dc:creator: @lesterknome lesterknome
item.description:
@lesterknome wrote:

  1. Boot into safe mode
  2. Install Malware anti-malware bytes
  3. Update it
  4. Scan
  5. Download and use CCleaner
  6. Don’t be an idiot

Read full topic

item.title: Help deleting a virus
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

I’ll try and explain this as basicly as possible.
Go into safe mode, but first download ccleaner, hijack this, and microsoft security essentials. When in safe mode scan with security essentials and run ccleaner to wipe all your internet files and free space (Set wipe free space on 7 passes). Then go into hijack this and look for svchost and replace it. You should be good after that.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Wet_Dreamss wrote:

I had the same thing, what i did, was turned my computer off for a couple days, because i went on vacation, then I turned it on and it was gone, I have Microsoft Security Essentials as my virus scanner/cleaner so
Try it with MSE
